title: List of Ig Nobel Prize winners - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: List of Ig Nobel Prize winners This is a list of Ig Nobel Prize winners from 1991 to the present day. [[1]](#cite_note-auto-1) A [parody](/wiki/Parody) of the [Nobel Prizes](/wiki/Nobel_Prize), the [Ig Nobel Prizes](/wiki/Ig_Nobel_Prize) are awarded each year in mid-September, around the time the recipients of the genuine Nobel Prizes are announced, for ten achievements that "first make people laugh, and then make them think". Commenting on the 2006 awards, [Marc Abrahams](/wiki/Marc_Abrahams), editor of [Annals of Improbable Research](/wiki/Annals_of_Improbable_Research) and co-sponsor of the awards, said that "[t]he prizes are intended to celebrate the unusual, honor the imaginative, and spur people's interest in science, medicine, and technology". [[2]](#cite_note-2) All prizes are awarded for real achievements, except for three in 1991 and one in 1994, due to an erroneous press release. 1991[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=1)] - Biology - [Robert Klark Graham](/wiki/Robert_Klark_Graham), selector of seeds and prophet of propagation, for his pioneering development of the [Repository for Germinal Choice](/wiki/Repository_for_Germinal_Choice), a [sperm bank](/wiki/Sperm_bank)that accepts - Chemistry - [Jacques Benveniste](/wiki/Jacques_Benveniste), prolific [proselytizer](/wiki/Proselytism)and dedicated correspondent of [Nature](/wiki/Nature_(journal)), for his persistent "discovery" that water, H2O, is an intelligent liquid, and for demonstrating to his satisfaction that water is able to remember events long after all traces of those events have vanished (see [water memory](/wiki/Water_memory), his proposed explanation for [homeopathy](/wiki/Homeopathy)). - Economics - [Michael Milken](/wiki/Michael_Milken), titan of Wall Street and father of the [junk bond](/wiki/Junk_bond), to whom the world is indebted. [[3]](#cite_note-3) [[4]](#cite_note-4) [[5]](#cite_note-5) - Education - [Dan Quayle](/wiki/Dan_Quayle), "consumer of time and occupier of space" (as well as the then- [U.S. Vice President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States)), for demonstrating, better than anyone else, the need for science education. - Literature - [Erich von Däniken](/wiki/Erich_von_D%C3%A4niken), visionary raconteur and author of [Chariots of the Gods?](/wiki/Chariots_of_the_Gods%3F), for explaining how human civilization was influenced by [ancient astronauts](/wiki/Ancient_astronauts)from outer space. - Medicine - Alan Kligerman, deviser of digestive deliverance, vanquisher of vapor, and inventor of [Beano](/wiki/Beano_(dietary_supplement)), for his pioneering work with anti-gas liquids that prevent bloat, gassiness, discomfort, and embarrassment. - Peace - [Edward Teller](/wiki/Edward_Teller), father of the [hydrogen bomb](/wiki/Hydrogen_bomb)and first champion of the [Star Wars weapons system](/wiki/Strategic_Defense_Initiative), for his lifelong efforts to change the meaning of peace as it is known. Apocryphal achievements[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=2)] The first nomination also featured three fictional recipients for fictional achievements. [[6]](#cite_note-6) - Interdisciplinary Research: [Josiah S. Carberry](/wiki/Josiah_S._Carberry), for his work in psychoceramics, " [cracked pots](/wiki/Crackpot_(person))". - Pedestrian Technology: [Paul DeFanti](/wiki/Paul_DeFanti), "wizard of structures and crusader for public safety, for his invention of the [Buckybonnet](/wiki/Buckyball_(molecule)), a [geodesic](/wiki/Geodesic)fashion structure that pedestrians wear to protect their heads and preserve their composure". - Physics: Thomas Kyle, for his discovery of "the heaviest element in the universe, [Administratium](/wiki/Administratium)". 1992[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=3)] - Archaeology - [Éclaireurs de France](/wiki/%C3%89claireurs_de_France)(a French Scouting organization), removers of [graffiti](/wiki/Graffiti), for damaging the prehistoric paintings of two [Bisons](/wiki/Bison)in the [Cave of Mayrière supérieure](/wiki/Cave_of_Mayri%C3%A8re_sup%C3%A9rieure)near the French village of [Bruniquel](/wiki/Bruniquel). [[7]](#cite_note-7) - Art - Presented jointly to Jim Knowlton, modern [Renaissance man](/wiki/Polymath), for his classic anatomy poster "Penises of the Animal Kingdom," and to the U.S. [National Endowment for the Arts](/wiki/National_Endowment_for_the_Arts), for encouraging Mr. Knowlton to extend his work in the form of a pop-up book. - Biology - [Dr. Cecil Jacobson](/wiki/Cecil_Jacobson), relentlessly generous sperm donor, and prolific patriarch of sperm banking, for devising a simple, single-handed method of quality control. - Chemistry - Ivette Bassa, constructor of colourful [colloids](/wiki/Colloid), for her role in the crowning achievement of 20th century chemistry, the synthesis of bright blue [Jell-O](/wiki/Jell-O). - Economics - The investors of [Lloyd's of London](/wiki/Lloyd%27s_of_London), heirs to 300 years of dull prudent management, for their bold attempt to ensure disaster by refusing to pay for their company's losses. - Literature - [Yuri Struchkov](/wiki/Yuri_Struchkov), [[8]](#cite_note-8)unstoppable author from the [Institute of Organoelement Compounds](/wiki/Nesmeyanov_Institute_of_Organoelement_Compounds) [[9]](#cite_note-9)in Moscow, for the 948 scientific papers he published between the years 1981 and 1990, averaging more than one every 3.9 days. - Medicine - F. Kanda, E. Yagi, M. Fukuda, K. Nakajima, T. Ohta, and O. Nakata of the [Shiseido](/wiki/Shiseido)Research Center in [Yokohama](/wiki/Yokohama), for their pioneering research study "Elucidation of Chemical Compounds Responsible for Foot Malodour," especially for their conclusion that people who think they have [foot odor](/wiki/Foot_odor)do, and those who don't, don't. [[10]](#cite_note-10) - Nutrition - The utilizers of [SPAM](/wiki/Spam_(food)), courageous consumers of canned comestibles, for 54 years of undiscriminating digestion. - Peace - [Daryl Gates](/wiki/Daryl_Gates), former police chief of the City of Los Angeles, for his uniquely compelling methods of [bringing people together](/wiki/1992_Los_Angeles_riots). - Physics - David Chorley and Doug Bower, lions of low-energy physics, for their circular contributions to field theory based on the [geometrical destruction of English crops](/wiki/Crop_circle). 1993[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=4)] - Biology - Presented jointly to Paul Williams Jr. of the Oregon State Health Division and Kenneth W. Newel of the [Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine](/wiki/Liverpool_School_of_Tropical_Medicine), bold biological detectives, for their pioneering study, "Salmonella Excretion in Joy-Riding Pigs". [[11]](#cite_note-11) - Chemistry Gaines Campbell of [Lookout Mountain, Tennessee](/wiki/Lookout_Mountain,_Tennessee), dedicated deliverers of fragrance, for inventing scent strips, the odious method by which perfume is applied to magazine pages. - Consumer Engineering - Presented to [Ron Popeil](/wiki/Ron_Popeil), incessant inventor and perpetual pitchman of [late night television](/wiki/Infomercials), for redefining the industrial revolution with such devices as the [Veg-O-Matic](/wiki/Veg-O-Matic), the Pocket Fisherman, Mr. Microphone, and the Inside-the-Shell Egg Scrambler. - Economics - Presented to [Ravi Batra](/wiki/Ravi_Batra)of [Southern Methodist University](/wiki/Southern_Methodist_University), shrewd economist and best-selling author of The Great Depression of 1990 ( [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) [978-0-440-20168-7](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-440-20168-7)) and Surviving the Great Depression of 1990, ( [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) [978-0-671-66324-7](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-671-66324-7)) for selling enough copies of his books to single-handedly prevent [worldwide economic collapse](/wiki/Depression_(economics)). - Literature - Presented to T. Morrison, E. Topol, R. Califf, F. Van de Werf, P. W. Armstrong, and their 972 co-authors, [[12]](#cite_note-12)for publishing a medical research paper which has one hundred times as many authors as pages. The authors are from the following countries: Australia, [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium), Canada, France, Germany, [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand), [Poland](/wiki/Poland), Spain, [Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland), the United Kingdom, and the United States. - Mathematics - Presented to [Robert W. Faid](/wiki/Robert_W._Faid)of [Greenville, South Carolina](/wiki/Greenville,_South_Carolina), farsighted and faithful seer of statistics, for calculating the exact odds (710,609,175,188,282,000 to 1) that [Mikhail Gorbachev](/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev)is the [Antichrist](/wiki/Antichrist). [[13]](#cite_note-13) - Medicine - Presented to James F. Nolan, Thomas J. Stillwell, and John P. Sands, Jr., medical men of mercy, for their painstaking research report, "Acute Management of the Zipper-Entrapped Penis". [[14]](#cite_note-14) - Peace - The [Pepsi-Cola Company of the Philippines](/wiki/Pepsi_Philippines), for sponsoring a [contest](/wiki/Pepsi_Number_Fever)to create a millionaire, and then announcing the wrong winning number, thereby inciting and uniting 800,000 riotously expectant winners, and bringing many warring factions together for the first time in their nation's history. [[15]](#cite_note-15) - Physics - Presented to [Corentin Louis Kervran](/wiki/Corentin_Louis_Kervran)of France, ardent admirer of [alchemy](/wiki/Alchemy), for his conclusion that the calcium in chickens' eggshells is created by a process of [cold fusion](/wiki/Cold_fusion). [[16]](#cite_note-16) - Psychology - Presented jointly Medical School](/wiki/Harvard_Medical_School)and [David M. Jacobs](/wiki/David_M._Jacobs)of [Temple University](/wiki/Temple_University), for their conclusion that people who believe they were [kidnapped by aliens from outer space](/wiki/Abduction_phenomenon), probably were—and especially for their conclusion, "the focus of the abduction is the production of children". [[17]](#cite_note-17) - Visionary Technology - Presented jointly to Jay Schiffman of [Farmington Hills, Michigan](/wiki/Farmington_Hills,_Michigan), crack inventor of AutoVision, an image projection device that makes it possible to drive a [car](/wiki/Automobile)and watch television at the same time, and to the [Michigan State Legislature](/wiki/Michigan_State_Legislature), for making it legal to do so. 1994[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=5)] - Biology - Presented to W. Brian Sweeney, Brian Krafte-Jacobs, Jeffrey W. Britton, and Wayne Hansen, for their breakthrough study, "The Constipated Serviceman: Prevalence Among Deployed US Troops," and especially for their numerical analysis of [bowel movement](/wiki/Bowel_movement)frequency. [[18]](#cite_note-18) - Chemistry - Presented to [Texas State Senator](/wiki/Texas_State_Senate) [Bob Glasgow](/wiki/Bob_Glasgow), writer of logical legislation, for sponsoring the 1989 drug control law which makes it illegal to purchase [beakers](/wiki/Beaker_(glassware)), [flasks](/wiki/Laboratory_flask), [test tubes](/wiki/Test_tube), or other [laboratory glassware](/wiki/Laboratory_glassware)without a permit. - Presented to Juan Pablo Dávila of [Chile](/wiki/Chile), tireless trader of financial futures and former employee of the state-owned company [Codelco](/wiki/Codelco), for instructing his computer to "buy" when he meant "sell". He subsequently attempted to recoup his losses by making increasingly unprofitable trades that [ultimately lost](/wiki/List_of_trading_losses)0.5 percent of Chile's [gross national product](/wiki/Gross_national_product). Davila's relentless achievement inspired his countrymen to coin a new verb, " [davilar](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/davilar)", meaning "to botch things up royally". - Entomology - Presented to Robert A. Lopez of [Westport, NY](/wiki/Westport,_NY), valiant [veterinarian](/wiki/Veterinarian)and so called friend of all creatures great and small, for his series of experiments in obtaining ear mites from cats, inserting them into his own ear, and carefully observing and analyzing the results. [[19]](#cite_note-19) - Literature - Presented to [L. Ron Hubbard](/wiki/L._Ron_Hubbard), ardent author of science fiction and founding father of [Scientology](/wiki/Scientology), for his crackling Good Book, [Dianetics](/wiki/Dianetics:_The_Modern_Science_of_Mental_Health), which is highly profitable to mankind, or to a portion thereof. - Mathematics - Presented to The [Southern Baptist](/wiki/Southern_Baptist_Convention)Church of [Alabama](/wiki/Alabama), mathematical measurers of [morality](/wiki/Morality), for their county-by-county estimate of how many Alabama citizens will go to [Hell](/wiki/Hell)if they don't repent. [[20]](#cite_note-20) - Medicine - Two prizes. First, to Patient X, formerly of the [US Marine Corps](/wiki/US_Marine_Corps), valiant victim of a venomous bite from his pet [rattlesnake](/wiki/Rattlesnake), for his determined use of [electroshock therapy](/wiki/Electroshock_therapy). At his own insistence, automobile [spark plug](/wiki/Spark_plug)wires were attached to his lip, and the car engine revved to 3,000 rpm for five minutes. Second, to Dr. Richard C. Dart of the Rocky Mountain Poison Center and Dr. Richard A. Gustafson of The [University of Arizona](/wiki/University_of_Arizona)Health Sciences Center, for their well-grounded medical report, "Failure of Electric Shock Treatment for Rattlesnake Envenomation." [[21]](#cite_note-21) - Peace - Presented to [John Hagelin](/wiki/John_Hagelin)of [Maharishi University](/wiki/Maharishi_University_of_Management)and The Institute of Science, Technology and Public Policy, for his experimental conclusion that 4,000 [trained meditators](/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation_technique)caused a 24 percent decrease in violent crime in Washington, D.C. [[22]](#cite_note-22) - Psychology - Presented to [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew), former [Prime Minister of Singapore](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore), for his thirty-year study of the effects of punishing three million citizens of Singapore whenever they spat, [chewed gum](/wiki/Chewing_gum_ban_in_Singapore), or fed pigeons. No longer officially listed[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=6)] - Physics - Presented to The [Japanese Meteorological Agency](/wiki/Japanese_Meteorological_Agency), for its seven-year study of whether earthquakes are caused by [catfish](/wiki/Namazu_(Japanese_mythology))wiggling their tails. This winner is not officially listed, as it was based on what turned out to be erroneous press accounts. [[23]](#cite_note-23) 1995[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=7)] The ceremony took place on 6 October 1995. [[24]](#cite_note-24) - Chemistry - Presented to [Bijan Pakzad](/wiki/Bijan_Pakzad)of [Beverly Hills](/wiki/Beverly_Hills), for creating DNA Cologne and DNA Perfume, neither of which contain [deoxyribonucleic acid](/wiki/Deoxyribonucleic_acid), and both of which come in a triple helix bottle. - Dentistry - Presented to Robert H. Beaumont, of [Shoreview, Minnesota](/wiki/Shoreview,_Minnesota), for his incisive study "Patient Preference for Waxed or Unwaxed Dental Floss". [[25]](#cite_note-25) - Economics - Presented jointly to at [Barings California](/wiki/Orange_County,_California)for using the [calculus](/wiki/Calculus)of [derivatives](/wiki/Derivative_(finance))to demonstrate that every financial institution has its limits. - Literature - Presented to David B. Busch and James R. Starling, of [Madison, Wisconsin](/wiki/Madison,_Wisconsin), for their research report, " [Rectal Foreign Bodies](/wiki/Rectal_foreign_body): Case Reports and a Comprehensive Review of the World's Literature." The citations include reports of, among other items: seven [light bulbs](/wiki/Light_bulb); a can](/wiki/Oil_can)with potato stopper; eleven different forms of fruits, vegetables and other foodstuffs; a [jeweler's saw](/wiki/Jeweler%27s_saw); a frozen pig's a [beer glass](/wiki/Beer_glass); and one patient's remarkable ensemble collection consisting of [spectacles](/wiki/Spectacles), a [suitcase](/wiki/Suitcase)key, a tobacco pouch and a magazine. [[26]](#cite_note-26) - Medicine - Presented to Marcia E. Buebel, David S. Shannahoff-Khalsa, and Michael R. Boyle, for their study entitled "The Effects of Unilateral Forced Nostril Breathing on Cognition." [[27]](#cite_note-27) - Nutrition - Presented to John Martinez of J. Martinez & Company in [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta), for [luak coffee](/wiki/Kopi_luwak), the world's most expensive coffee, which is made from coffee beans ingested and excreted by the [luak](/wiki/Luak), a bobcat-like animal native to [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia). - Peace - Presented to the [Legislative Yuan](/wiki/Legislative_Yuan)of the [Republic of China](/wiki/Republic_of_China)( [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan)), for demonstrating that "politicians gain more by [punching, kicking and gouging each other](/wiki/Legislative_violence#Republic_of_China_(Taiwan))than by waging war against other nations". - Physics - Presented to Dominique M.R. Georget, R. Parker, and Andrew C. Smith of [Norwich](/wiki/Norwich), England, for their rigorous analysis of soggy [breakfast cereal](/wiki/Breakfast_cereal). It was published in the report entitled "A Study of the Effects of Water Content on the Compaction Behaviour of Breakfast Cereal Flakes." [[28]](#cite_note-28) - Psychology - Presented to and Masumi Wakita, of [Keio University](/wiki/Keio_University), for their success in training [pigeons](/wiki/Pigeons)to discriminate between the paintings of [Picasso](/wiki/Picasso)and those of [Monet](/wiki/Monet). [[29]](#cite_note-29) - Public Health - Presented Martha Kold Bakkevig of Sintef Unimed in [Trondheim](/wiki/Trondheim), [Norway](/wiki/Norway), and Ruth Nielsen of the [Technical University of Denmark](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Denmark), for their exhaustive study, "Impact of Wet Underwear on Thermoregulatory Responses and Thermal Comfort in the Cold." [[30]](#cite_note-30) 1996[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=8)] The ceremony took place on 3 October 1996. [[31]](#cite_note-31) - Art - Presented to [Don Featherstone](/wiki/Donald_Featherstone_(artist))of [Fitchburg, Massachusetts](/wiki/Fitchburg,_Massachusetts), his ornamentally evolutionary invention, the [plastic pink flamingo](/wiki/Plastic_flamingo). Featherstone was the first Ig Nobel Prize winner to appear in person at the awards ceremony to accept the award. [[32]](#cite_note-32) - Biodiversity - Presented to [Chonosuke Okamura](/wiki/Chonosuke_Okamura)of the Okamura Fossil Laboratory in [Nagoya, Japan](/wiki/Nagoya,_Japan), for discovering the fossils of [dinosaurs](/wiki/Dinosaur), horses, [dragons](/wiki/Dragon), and more than one thousand other extinct "mini-species", each of which is less than 0.25 mm in length. - Biology - Presented jointly to Anders Bærheim and Hogne Sandvik of the [University of Bergen](/wiki/University_of_Bergen), Norway, for their report, "Effect of Ale, Garlic, and Soured Cream on the Appetite of Leeches." [[33]](#cite_note-33) - Chemistry - Presented to [George Goble](/wiki/George_H._Goble)of [Purdue University](/wiki/Purdue_University), for his blistering world record time for igniting a barbecue grill: three seconds, using [charcoal](/wiki/Charcoal)and [liquid oxygen](/wiki/Liquid_oxygen). [[34]](#cite_note-34) - Economics - Presented to Dr. Robert J. Genco of the [University at Buffalo](/wiki/University_at_Buffalo,_The_State_University_of_New_York)for his discovery that "financial strain is a risk indicator for destructive periodontal disease." [[35]](#cite_note-35) - Literature - Presented to the editors of the journal [Social Text](/wiki/Social_Text)for publishing a paper composed under deceptive pretenses that couched an absurd but theoretically specialized argument about the nature of gravity in a mire of academic buzzwords associated with humanities departments. (See [Sokal Affair](/wiki/Sokal_Affair)for details). - Medicine chairman of [Brown and Williamson Tobacco Company](/wiki/Brown_%26_Williamson), for their unshakable discovery, as testified to the [U.S. Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress), that [nicotine](/wiki/Nicotine)is not addictive. - Peace - Presented to [Jacques Chirac](/wiki/Jacques_Chirac), [President of France](/wiki/President_of_France), for commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of [Hiroshima](/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki)with [atomic bomb tests in the Pacific](/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_French_nuclear_tests). - Physics - Presented to [Robert Matthews](/wiki/Robert_Matthews_(scientist))of [Aston University](/wiki/Aston_University), England, for his studies of [Murphy's Law](/wiki/Murphy%27s_Law), and especially for demonstrating that toast often falls on the buttered side. [[36]](#cite_note-36) - Public Health - Presented to Ellen Kleist of [Nuuk, Greenland](/wiki/Nuuk,_Greenland)and Harald Moi of [Oslo](/wiki/Oslo), [Norway](/wiki/Norway), for their cautionary of Gonorrhea Through an Inflatable Doll." [[37]](#cite_note-37) 1997[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=9)] The ceremony took place on 9 October 1997. [[38]](#cite_note-38) - Astronomy - Presented to [Richard C. Hoagland](/wiki/Richard_C._Hoagland)of [New Jersey](/wiki/New_Jersey), for identifying artificial features on [Mars](/wiki/Mars), including a human [face on Mars](/wiki/Face_on_Mars)and ten-mile high buildings on the far side of the moon. [[39]](#cite_note-39) - Biology - Presented to T. Yagyu and his colleagues from the University Hospital of [Zurich](/wiki/Zurich), Switzerland, the Kansai Medical University in [Osaka](/wiki/Osaka), Japan, and the Neuroscience Technology Research in [Prague](/wiki/Prague), Czech Republic, for measuring people's brainwave patterns while they chewed different flavors of [gum](/wiki/Bubble_gum). [[40]](#cite_note-40) - Communications - Presented to [Sanford Wallace](/wiki/Sanford_Wallace), president of Cyber Promotions of [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia). Nothing has stopped this self-appointed courier from delivering [electronic junk mail](/wiki/E-mail_spam)to all the world. - Economics - Presented to Akihiro Yokoi of Wiz Company in [Chiba](/wiki/Chiba_Prefecture), Japan, and Aki Maita of [Bandai](/wiki/Bandai)Company in Tokyo, for diverting millions of man-hours of work into the husbandry of [virtual pets](/wiki/Virtual_pets). - Entomology - Presented to Mark Hostetler of the [University of Florida](/wiki/University_of_Florida), for his book, That Gunk on Your Car, ( [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) [978-0-89815-961-5](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-89815-961-5)) which identifies the insect splats that appear - Literature - Presented Doron Witztum, [Eliyahu Rips](/wiki/Eliyahu_Rips), and Yoav Rosenberg of [Israel](/wiki/Israel), and to Michael Drosnin of the United States, for their claimed statistical discovery of a hidden [code in the Bible](/wiki/Bible_Code). [[41]](#cite_note-41) - Medicine - Presented to Carl J. Charnetski and Francis X. Brennan, Jr. of [Wilkes University](/wiki/Wilkes_University), and James F. Harrison of [Muzak](/wiki/Muzak_Holdings)Ltd. in [Seattle, Washington](/wiki/Seattle), for their discovery that listening to [Muzak](/wiki/Elevator_music)stimulates immunity system production and thus may help prevent the [common cold](/wiki/Common_cold). [[42]](#cite_note-42) - Meteorology - Presented to [Bernard Vonnegut](/wiki/Bernard_Vonnegut)of the [State University of New York at Albany](/wiki/University_at_Albany,_SUNY), for his report, "Chicken Plucking as Measure of Tornado Wind Speed." [[43]](#cite_note-43) - Peace - Presented to [Harold Hillman](/wiki/Harold_Hillman)of the [University of Surrey](/wiki/University_of_Surrey), England, for his report "The Possible Pain Experienced During Execution by Different Methods." [[44]](#cite_note-44) - Physics - Presented to [John Bockris](/wiki/John_Bockris)of [Texas A&M University](/wiki/Texas_A%26M_University), for his achievements in [cold fusion](/wiki/Cold_fusion), in the [transmutation of base elements into gold](/wiki/Alchemy), and in the electrochemical incineration of domestic rubbish. 1998[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=10)] The ceremony took place on 8 October 1998. [[45]](#cite_note-45) - Chemistry - Presented to [Jacques Benveniste](/wiki/Jacques_Benveniste)of France, for his [homeopathic](/wiki/Homeopathy)"discovery" that not only does water have [memory](/wiki/Memory), but that the information can be transmitted over [telephone lines](/wiki/Telephone_line)and the Internet. [[46]](#cite_note-46) - Biology - Presented to Peter Fong of [Gettysburg College](/wiki/Gettysburg_College), [Gettysburg, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Gettysburg,_Pennsylvania), for contributing to the happiness of [clams](/wiki/Clams)by giving them [Prozac](/wiki/Prozac). [[47]](#cite_note-47) - Economics - Presented to [Richard Seed](/wiki/Richard_Seed)of Chicago for his efforts to stoke up the world economy by [cloning](/wiki/Cloning)himself and other [human beings](/wiki/Human_being). [[48]](#cite_note-48) - Literature - Presented to Dr. Mara Sidoli of [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C.), for her illuminating report, "Farting as a Defence Against Unspeakable Dread". [[49]](#cite_note-49) - Medicine - Presented to Patient Y and to his doctors, Caroline Mills, Meirion Llewelyn, David Kelly, and Peter Holt, of [Royal Gwent Hospital](/wiki/Royal_Gwent_Hospital), in [Newport](/wiki/Newport,_Wales)for the cautionary medical report, "A Man Who Pricked His Finger and Smelled Putrid for 5 Years." [[50]](#cite_note-50) - Peace - Presented to [Prime peaceful detonations of [atomic - Physics - Presented to [Deepak Chopra](/wiki/Deepak_Chopra)of The Chopra Center for Well Being, [La Jolla](/wiki/La_Jolla), California, for his unique interpretation of [quantum physics](/wiki/Quantum_physics)as it applies to life, liberty, and the pursuit of economic happiness. [[51]](#cite_note-51) - Safety Engineering - Presented to [Troy Hurtubise](/wiki/Troy_Hurtubise), of [North Bay, Ontario](/wiki/North_Bay,_Ontario), for developing and personally testing a suit of armor that is impervious to [grizzly bears](/wiki/Grizzly_bears). - Science Education - Presented to Dolores Krieger, Professor Emerita, [New York University](/wiki/New_York_University), for demonstrating the merits of [therapeutic touch](/wiki/Therapeutic_touch), a method by which nurses manipulate the energy fields of ailing patients by carefully avoiding physical contact with those patients. - Statistics - Presented to Jerald Bain of Mt. Sinai Hospital in [Toronto](/wiki/Toronto)and Kerry Siminoski of the [University of Alberta](/wiki/University_of_Alberta), for their carefully measured report, "The Relationship Among Height, Penile Length, and Foot Size". [[52]](#cite_note-52) 1999[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=11)] The ceremony took place on 30 September 1999. [[53]](#cite_note-53) - Biology - Presented to Dr. Paul Bosland, director of [The Chile Pepper Institute](/wiki/Chile_Pepper_Institute), [New Mexico spiceless pepper](/wiki/Chili_pepper). - Chemistry - [[86]](#cite_note-86) - Psychology - Presented to Gian Vittorio Caprara and Claudio Barbaranelli of the and Zimbardo](/wiki/Philip_Zimbardo)of [[87]](#cite_note-87) 2004[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Ig_Nobel_Prize_winners&action=edit§ion=16)] The ceremony took place on 30 September 2004. - Biology - Presented to Ben Wilson of the [University of British Columbia](/wiki/University_of_British_Columbia), Lawrence Dill of [Simon Fraser University](/wiki/Simon_Fraser_University), Canada, Robert Batty of the Scottish Association for Marine Science, Magnus Wahlberg of the [University of Aarhus](/wiki/University_of_Aarhus), [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark), and Håkan Westerberg of [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden)'s National Board of for showing that [herrings](/wiki/Herring)apparently communicate by [farting](/wiki/Flatulence). [[88]](#cite_note-88) [[89]](#cite_note-89) - It has been suggested that the study of this phenomenon has had major political consequences. Following the [sensational stranding of a Soviet submarine](/wiki/Soviet_submarine_S-363)deep inside Swedish waters on 27 October 1981, the Swedish navy initiated a large-scale campaign to guard Swedish territorial waters from the perceived threat of infiltration by foreign submarines, despite [the Soviets](/wiki/Soviet_Union)consistently asserting that the stranding had occurred due to navigational errors. The ["submarine hunts"](/wiki/Swedish_submarine_incidents), which lasted throughout the 1980s and early 1990s, have been a heavily debated issue in Sweden, as to whether or not there ever was any factual substance to the claims of Soviet infiltration. One widely reported piece of "evidence" were several sound recordings of what the Swedish navy suspected to be foreign submarines. Oceanographers and marine biologists were invited to study the recordings and would eventually find that the sounds heard were most probably produced not by submarines, but in fact were the noises made when herring passed gas. In a reportage by the Swedish science magazine "Vetenskapens värld" ("World of science") televised on 16 April 2012, it's suggested that these findings were important in putting an end to the costly "submarine hunts" which had continued for more than a decade, with Ig Nobel laureate Håkan Westerberg guessing that this would have saved Swedish tax payers hundreds of millions in [SEK](/wiki/Swedish_krona).
